BEFORE THE GRIPES-
Game is, at the very least, totally worth the money. If you have nothing else to spend it on and you want to have a fun time with a friend then this is definetely a good option. Ton of fun to be had getting murdered with your buds. Just don't take the game too seriously because it's a mess right now.

That being said.

Going to TRY to keep it short because this is not a legit review. Never thought I would write one of these Uninstalled until they fix this" reviews. I loved this game for what it was but I cannot even play it in it's current state anymore.

The devs seem to be systematically removing all the fun from this game. The mechanics were perfect and they get ruined every patch. Skill determined if you won a fight. Now it depends on the random loot you aquire and a muddled messy spamfest melee system. Perks worked together too in a way that encouraged experimentation. No "class" you chose seemed to feel like a bad choice. Now you'd be lucky to feel good about anything that you choose. Blocking was sneaky
date: and had to be timed well or you would be punished. Now it just doesn't work. It just... wont work! If that wasn't bad enough
recommended: somehow each patch they break mechanics by accident. They seemingly don't do any sufficient testing before releasing a patch. For example throwing items in the game would cause the object to float infront of your face
hoursPlayed: then teleport to where ever it would of landed 2 seconds later --.-- This ones been fixed but it's not the only example.\n\nI should mention that anyone and EVERYONE who complained that the fighting in this game was cheap or that it was broken BEFORE the past couple patches (4/13?) simply did not understand HOW TO PLAY THE GAME well enough to know what they were doing wrong. Everyone runs to the center of the arena
I ruin a duel by killing one of the duelers
The other guy runs away in fear as I collect my price from a blue box
I pickup a javelin and throw it at someones face
As they lay dead on the ground an arrow flies past me
I dodge the second arrow matrix style and start a battle with the last peasent
We play cat and mouse for a while and then I die in pity

10/10 would kill someone with a branch again

But all in all. This game is for anyone who wants to beat innocent people as they want to beat you. The game has a competitive vibe to it. As if a competition for your life wouldn't be enough!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy ♥♥♥♥, the day I bought the game there was around 250 reviews, couple hours later 400s. Now that I finally open up the game, almost 2.5k reviews? This game sure is growing fast and for good reasons. If you ever wanted a stand alone hunger game experience, this is the one.

Graphics are decent and the crafting system is reasonable. There are large variety of melee weapons and some ranged weapons. The melee weapons range from your knives and swords, to bludge, or even chainsaw. Range weapons include blow guns, bows, and modern weaponry. Everyone starts with nothing, unless you created a loadout that included some utitliy.

You start the game picking up stones and sticks to craft basic weapons or traps, and you adventure to collect power ups or random utilities that can be deconstructed to give you money. With enough money you can call in air drops, but you do need to guard your air drop location until it arrives.

There are random events during the game that will attract players to certain locations.

Pros:
-One of the few, or only, Hunger Game clone.
-Decent for 15.
-Graphics are nice, not photo realistic but enough.
-Supports different play styles, kinda.

Cons:
-Minor motion sickness.
-Controls are odd at times.

Overall:
Get this if you can spare 15 dollars, it is most certainly worth it. Not sure what to do with this when player base dies, since it is after all, a Hunger Games clone, and you can't play the Hunger Games without a player base. But as for the moment, it is certainly a must. And let the odds be ever in your favor.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Culling is a pretty cool battle royal-style game that allows you to play free-for-all or with a friend to take on the other contestants. Graphics are good, controls are easy to understant, and they give you a crafting guide so you don't have to waste time trying to figure out how to make things. This is basically The Hunger Games in video game form and that isn't a bad thing at all.

The only thing that I do not like about the game is that the prize for first place is the same as the prize for anyone else who does enough damage to get one. If they could set up a reward system that gives the people who place first, second, and third something other than a clothing item, or at least multiple clothing items, I think more people would enjoy playing since they would get more of a reward.

All-in-all I love playing the game in both free-for-all and in teams. Its really fun and really addicting. I would recommend getting it if you like this style of battle royale games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On the whole, this is a great game with a lot of potential! However, there are some drawbacks, but there isn't anything majorly game breaking, and for £10.99, this is very worth it.

first of all, the overall feel of the game is amazing, the game is super immersive, and tense as f*ck during moments of combat, and when scavenging around for those vital supplies. You can play the game in many different styles; for example, you may chose to craft yourself basic weapons using rocks and branches which you may find lying about, or by hitting rocks or trees, or you may save up your F.U.N.C (in game currency used for crafting, healing, opening crates, calling in drops) to either open crates, or call in one of your drops (however this usually results in you hiding, and being sneaky until you gather enough F.U.N.C, and may result in you being dead before you can open your crate, or call in a drop.)

The perk system contains a wide variety of perks, ranging from offensive, defensive, and utility perks, all of which can be paired up with eachother, allowing players to make very powerful combinations, and with the right drop, you can be very deadly to other players. However, the perk system is a little bit over powered at the moment (in my opinion.) For example, there are perks allowing you to achieve +15% damage on all weapons, or spawn with a man tracker (allows you to track any enemies within a 99 meter radius, aslong as you are standing still.) And I would like to see the perks being nerfed a little bit, as sometimes its very hard to win against a guy with a full set of defensive, or offensive perks.

Furthermore, the combat system is quite weak at the moment, it feels very cheap in a sense, and very cluttered. If you are playing against players that are lagging, you'll find it very hard to block or counter attack their hits, and sometimes you may find yourslef or your opponent just mashing the attack button, until you can't block or counter them, which is quite unbalanced. If the combat is redone, this game would pretty much be perfect.

Overall though, I definitely recommend this game, especially as its only £10.99, and the only microtransactions are for cosmetic items (which are very easy to get, as you get 1 skin per game, aslong as you don't die straight away.) I just really hope the devs don't ditch/sell out (cough cough, h1z1.)



Positives:
Very well designed arena
Pretty good graphics
Good-ish performance on mid-ranged PC's
Very intense and fun!
Definitely worth the price
Easy to get cosmetic items

Negatives:
Combat feels cheap/random at times
Some weapons need further balance

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Culling. A last man standing multiplayer deathmatch game with survival elements (basic crafting, looting, basic resource gathering). It's a Battle Royale-esque game (though more like The Condemned IMO), that takes place inside a dome with 16 contestants and up to 25 minute rounds.

The game itself has a good concept but overall it feels quite cheap.

The melee combat system uses a rock, paper, scissors mechanism consisting of attack, block & shove. The balancing with the system is fine IMO, no complaints here. (Shoving briefly staggers the opponent or 'defeats' their block for those wondering.)

The system is quite clunky in its current state though. Seeing as melee combat is essentially the main aspect of the game, it is quite disappointing. The feedback when you land a blow or get struck isn't great either. Rust has better melee feedback (& that isn't saying much).

Add bad netcode and high latency servers on top of that and it just feels very sloppy. (AWS cloud servers btw.. Horrible for real-time/twitch games. I hope they eventually move to proper dedicated servers!)

I understand it's in Early Access, but compared to the other Early Access games I've played, this is lacking. I really wanted to like this game but the basic elements that make up the core gameplay have been ...I wouldn't say poorly but rather, crudely executed.

Honestly, I would probably come back to this game sometime in the future once more time has been spent developing the core mechanics. I see a promising future ahead for this game as long as they iron out the kinks and continue working on and improving the current foundations of the game, but I don't see that happening for at least another 6+ months so that's why I cannot recommend the game at this point in time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHello, I first saw this game when Summit1g was streaming on Twitch, and I thought wow! This game looks amazing. reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing game with quiet a lot of depth for early access. Can't wait to see what else the dev's add to this gem.

To expand:
+Patches every two weeks adding content and balancing. (Hotfixing bad patches)
+The two game modes (FFA and 2 man teams) are plenty for EA and both play extremely different to the other.
+Can play the game any number of ways
+Melee combat is rock/paper/sissors battle (With a few tricks) that often ends in an addrenaline rush.
+Ranged combat is balanced with good bow play being strong but not unstopable. Often used just to weaken opponents before entering melee combat.
+Guns/explosives while being the strongest weapons in the game are hard to aquire without putting yourself at a disadvantage and lack ammo which balances them well.
+An amazing announcer.
+Not much in gaming can match the feeling of excitement/addrenaline of your first FFA win.
+You'll have a lot of stories about your games when your friends finally log in.

=Only one map, however its so big and games are so unique in the way they play out that it doesn't get old.
=Unlocking all the airdrops are fun and quite challenging however once they are all unlocked there isn't much progression.

-A few annoying bugs. (They get fixed quickly)
-Dev's released a game breaking patch. (Hotfixed 2-3 days later without fully reverting the patch)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game was okay, but the one thing I can't stand that has put me off the thought of this game, and has contributed to me only spending less than an hour to the game, was the pure clunkyness while walking. It blows my mind how people can carry on playing this game, fair enough it is in Alpha still, but man, once I started pressing WASD, my head was about to explode.

I was about the whitey, just made me feel sick from how the movement is implemented into this game, so clunky it feels like I'm playing with a character who can't even move left and right without stuttering, and the walking is just too slow and stuttery. The whole game just feels a bit too broken atm, however I make myself clear that all in all this game has potential, however right now, the movement just puts me off the game.

TL;DR: basically can be a good game, only thing that put me off was the movement of the character, if you get headache's/light headed easily, or vulnerable to heavy motion sickness then this game is not for you. You will play it for around 10 minutes, then quit the game and lie on your bed and just feel like complete ♥♥♥♥ like what happened to me.

8/10 game if movement was fixed, as it is now though I give it a 2/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The culling USE to be an amazing game. I bought it the day it came out and played the hell out of ever since (~330 hours). The game was fast-paced, had a learning curve and even at top-end gameplay had a considerable amount of skill involved. This all changed 3-4 weeks ago with changes to their core combat system. We've waited through a few patches (and hotfixes) hoping the combat would be restored. No such luck. Instead, the devs focused on shiny cosmetics and random experimentation with weapon stats that served to simply imbalance the game. If you want a detailed example of the sloppy combat, see below. Before, when two people fought it consisted of a well-coordinated dance of blocks/jabs/charge attacks/pushes/jukes/out smarting. As of right now, this game is literally a random slug-fest. Two people face each other and it's a random spam fest of jabbing and push-spamming. If you try to block, you're punished (see below). It's a game of rock-paper-scissors with rock not working properly. Really sad, this game had potential. Too bad devs prefer shiny female clothing over core combat fixes.

If you buy the culling you're presented with a game with SLOPPY combat. Best way to describe this is with the following example: In The Culling, if you block and somebody attacks you, they become staggered and are stunned for ~1 second, giving you the oppurtunity to hit them. If you are blocking and somebody pushes you, you become staggered, leaving yourself vulnerable for ~1 second for them to attack you. In the current system, if I block an attack and then STOP blocking and somebody pushes me it shouldn't stagger me...but it does. The game is that sloppy that it still registers me as blocking and thus punishes me with a stagger (I have fibre op internet, 80 ms ping, etc, nothing has changed on my end, just the sloppy game)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe culling is a 16 man hunger games which you have 25 minutes to be the last alive. This game is mainly based on melee fights and crafting stuff to survive. The concept of the game is fantastic BUT some gameplay issues kinda ruined the game. Playing with a friend can be fun and rewarding but playing solo is just frustrating. The waiting time to get in a game is about 3-4 minutes and most of the times you get killed early once in a game. The combat system is kinda frustrating aswell where sometimes you find yourself in a situation where you can basicaly do nothing like 1v1 someone who stuns you with a stun gun then shoot you with an smg. And why not put 8 man solo games instead of 16? This would solved 2 big problems (frustration of getting killed fast and reduce the waiting time before games) If you're a casual gamer who play games for fun, don't buy this game if you don't have friends to play with. You just can't play this game alone without getting salty. On the other hand, if you have friends to play with go ahead and buy it. My review is MIXED and i chose thumbs down because there's no MIXED button.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played a game of The Culling and this is what happened...

Better love story than twilight:

I started of close to a river and I will soon begin my journey to find my comrade (lover") ;).
I crafted a spear and was on my to him. I will call him Stevie because I don't remember his name.
Suddenly he wrote "Hi. I love you".
I was a little suprised but I wrote back "I love you too".

I met him at a bridge and I knew it was love at first sight. We did some weird ♥♥♥♥ on that bridge and I think you don't want to know what.

Later on we began our search for loot. We didn't find much but randomly he pepper sprayed me in the face. I thought it was a little kinky first but I didn't think much about it. So we carried on our hunt for loot or people. We was at the gas station when suddenly he wrote "boom :D". He had triggered a bomb just for fun. He nearly blew us up and I and so was he pretty damaged by it. I got some suspicions that Stevie might have been a little crazy but I still loved him no matter what.

Now we were on a hunt to kill people and when we suddenly heard the noise if a chainsaw. We kept walking until we got to the airport. We wore crouching in a busch and soon we were fighting against a guy at the airport. We were pretty close to killing the person but his backup arrived. It was the guy with the chainsaw from earlier. I freaked out because they were killing Stevie and It was this moment Stevie and I knew we ♥♥♥♥ed up. I looked at him. He looked at me. He was lying on the ground. He whispered "Leave me behind....Run Clarence Run!". Okay that didn't happen but I was looking back at him getting slaughtered by the chainsaw man and his comrade. They was very close to me know as I was running for my life. I could feel his heavy breathing on my neck but little did I know that was the end of me. He shoved his chainsaw up my butt. It was hard and cold and at the moment I was lying dead pretty close to my love.

I quit the game and said to myself "Wow that was an intresting game" and now I'm sitting here writing about my adventures of this awesome game. It's definitely a game to check out and consider to purchase the game. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

No regrets. 10/10 would play this game again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is going to give me an aneurysm one day and I absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing despise it but I am also madly in love and will throw a spear at anyone who speaks ill of it.

The pros-
I get to ruin someone's day, multiple times per day
I get to hone my combat strategy for the inevitable Battle Royale Act
Me obviously cus I'm a pro

The cons-
You will get AIDS
You will want to murder the closest human pretty much every time you lose
Sometimes this game makes me very sad

In all seriousness, this game is going to be something great and it has been most enjoyable to be a part of the development. The devs work hard and release regular updates, although they do feel very experimental. Currently, the combat system is beyond clunky and feels rather gimmicky.

Never before in a game have I felt like an absolute madman one moment and then a complete scrub the next. It's very variable and you will want to bash your head into a wall on occasion.

But if there is one thing that will ring true forever, it's that the victories feel so gloriously sweet and all the salt you accumulated will suddenly disappear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really neat game. The design is rock solid except for its most important element: Combat. Let's start with the good stuff:

This is my kind of survival experience

One of my biggest complaints about most survival games is that most of them expect you to want your time to be wasted. The Culling doesn't, and I think that's really commendable. The game's basic mode (and my favorite) is an FFA, Battle Royale-style (or Hunger Games for those who haven't seen the best survival movie of all time) murderfest. Unlike long-term survival games (think Day Z, Rust, and the one with the Dinosaurs in it), The Culling's base mode boils down all of the worst-case-scenario social interactions that make these games so great into about 20 minutes.

Deciding, for example, whether to try to punch out a spear-wielding sociopath because I decided to make a beeline for the lootable building near my spawn and came up empty is a really powerful feeling.

Crafting, Mood and pacing

To get it out of the way: Yes, you punch trees in The Culling. Unlike most crafty survival games, however, the absurd practice of lumber-fisticuffs sorta makes sense within the tongue-in-cheek setting. You don't punch trees because there's no other logical way to find resources, you punch trees because trees make sticks and you only need two to bandage your bleeding gut.

Crafting is quick, satisfying and completely fits into the gameshow-y atmosphere. You'll spend most of your time collecting weapons,  salvaging them for FUNC (the game's primary resource) and then using that FUNC to either open in-world boxes or to call down a wide variety of airdropped equipment.

Barring specific airdropped equipment, almost all progression in The Culling is based entirely around a single game. You won't ever see a perk that you haven't unlocked yet. I think that's great. Instead of working your way up a crafting tree, I've found that most character builds focus on easy-to-grasp playstyles.

The two best examples off the top of my head is the close-range helldemon and the gun-wielding stealthlord. Both of these builds force players to scrounge for as much FUNC as they can get their hands on, but specific perk choices (you can pick 3) mean that they'll probably have to go about it differently.

Close-range characters are best at murdering their enemies in the first phase of the game. He/she will probably pick up a sprint, health, and damage buff for their melee weapon of choice. They'll craft a weapon as quickly as possible then scout around buildings for any suspiciously-open doors or lockers. From there, successfulling ambushing enough targets will earn them enough to get their hands on an airdropped chainsaw. The chainsaw is deadly, satisfying and a beautiful cherry on top of any melee build.

Long-range characters don't have to resort to murder, and instead will usually pick silent running, bow/gun aim buffs, and either a craft or trap bonus. They'll run around the map, hunting down FUNC through strategically placed skulls and energy containers. Bows, while functional and craft-friendly, aren't generally able to take out a bludgeon-wielding sociopath hopped up on whatever stims he's picked up in an abandoned research facility. With luck and enough moxie, he/she'll airdrop an extremely powerful rifle, then be tasked with killing enough players to deal with its prohibitively expensive ammunition cost.

There's a massive range between these two playstyles, but those're the two I've had some real fun with.

The combat is real bad.

My eternal love for melee-focused first-person titles like Chivalry lead me to one conclusion after about 20 hours of The Culling: Rock, paper, scissors doesn't work all that well in a twitch combat experience. This part gets tough to explain, but bear with me.

The basic combat is as follows:

- Left-click attacks, and can be held down to charge a heavily-damaging strike.
- Right click blocks, and will block any melee attack (not sure if chainsaws are included here) facing the front of the defender's hitbox.
- Q (or whatever) shoves your opponent, intended to punish someone for blocking too long.
- Blocked attacks cause the attacker to stagger for a moment, offering the defender a chance to take a quick swing.

Seems simple enough, right?

Sadly, the system's simplicity means that there's not a whole lot of room for weapon specialization, aim or consistency within the game's confrontations. Most of my success has come from exploiting the game's floaty hitboxes and not-quite-accurate animations to score cheap shots on opponents who didn't search the culling combat tricks" on YouTube.

My other move was to start charging an attack
date: wait for the opponent to block
recommended: and then cancel out of it by quickly pressing the right mouse button to follow up with a shove. I'm not sure if this is an exploit or not
hoursPlayed: but it doesn't make me feel all that good.\n\nUsing Chivalry's system as an example
voteText: I'd really like to see location based damage
helpfulPercent: multiple swing-styles and more uniqueness added to each melee weapon type (knives
votesHelpful: bludgeons and spears). Fast weapons shouldn't punish their users as harshly for blocking
votesTotal: while stronger weapons should command a wider arc in front of their wielder. Rock
votesFunny: paper
commentsCount: scissors is a great starting point
column16: but each weapon should offer its own set of rock
column17: paper and scissor options to increase the game's skill-ceiling.\n\nWith all of that said
column18: though
column19: The Culling is one of the freshest takes that I've seen on a quickly-tiring formula. All praise be to the developers of the game
column20: and one idea: Let players pay money to have your announcer VA record lines for them. It's another source of revenue
column21: and streamer-types would probably go wild."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA perfect example of how to ruin a game with poorly implemented patches. What started as a great game with much promise has been ruined by endless tinkering, poor performance and bad decision making that has driven off most of the community. It has gotten so bad I had to delete my positive review and write this instead. This game used to run at a solid 50-60fps on one GTX 970 (forget it noticing your SLI, gave up on that one a while ago) and now runs at a slideshow like 20fps no matter WHAT the setting. The combat is a mess, the patches just fix one problem with the combat, while adding 10 other issues. The community has been driven to record low levels so in some areas you will have long wait times. They may still be able to bring this game back to greatness, but it is going to take some work. I will update if this happens.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It was down to a 1 v 1. I had bided my time the entire match, slinking in the shadows, only fighting when I knew I would win. The last three games I had died within the first five minutes, it was a rough losing streak, but I promised myself I would at least get a kill this round. That kill would be my first. A poor unsuspectng man in a red shirt peacfully crafting a bandage was my first target. I slowly crept around the bushes and contemplated if combat was worth the risk, after all I had been taken out so swiftly the last rounds. But no, my time was now. I raised my hammer. Before he knew what was happening I bludgeoned red shirt man in the back of his head. It took a couple more hits to finish him off, but within the next few moments i had finished the deed. It was exhilarating, my first kill in 3 hours.

I quickly searched the red shirt mans body and found a claymore. I had to make a split second decision, claymore or mantracker, as I had yet to aquire a backpack and only had three slots. With great sorrow I dropped the mantracker and picked up the explosive, wondering if it was worth it, considering I hadn't used one before. Little did I know, that very claymore would be the exact reason I would win. After being chased, shot, and hunted for the next ten minutes, I eventually made my way to the center, as stage one had initiated and the gas was beginning to push contestants towards the center. I stupidly ran around the center for a few minutes, wondering when people would show up. When nobody did, I realized how idiotic waiting in the arena was, and I slunk back into the shrubbery, but not before throwing my claymore on the wall. As I waited in the trees another contestant was killed. Curious who was left I glanced up into the sky. I was shocked to see it was down to one more contestant and myself. 1 V 1. One on One. Mono a Mono.

I'll admit, I was a little panicked. I had never gotten a kill before this match, let alone won an entire Culling. I decided my best course of action was to wait it out, see my opponent first, and try to use the element of suprise. Suddenly an explosion went off and I jumped, afraid that I was going to die, but then I realized what had happened. My opponent had set off my claymore! Now was the time to strike! Mustering my courage I charged forward, hammer held high, and I promply got shot with an arrow. Ignoring the wound I found my injured enemy and smacked the bow from his hands with a swift attack. He reeled back drawing his sword, holding it steady. We fought back and fourth, my hammer against his sword, neither of us gaining an advantage. That is until I did something very foolish.

I threw my hammer. My hammer smashed into my enemy dropping him very low on HP. However, I had hoped it would kill him, and now the only weapon I had was a crafted bow. Standing between me and my hammer, the final contestant advanced towards me, cutting me up good before I managed to retreat to a safe distance. It was anybodys game at this point, both myself and my opponent were one good hit away from death. I pulled out my bow, taking two panic shots, missing both; barely dodging his counter attack. Finally I knocked one last arrow, carefully aiming; and knew that this shot would decide whether I won or lost this match. The time I took to aim meant their was no retreat if I missed. It was do or die. My opponent charged me, sword at the ready, jumping up to deliver a final blow. By reflex I pulled my shot up, praying the arrow would fly true. I released the bolt, closing my eyes, sure that I had missed and lay dead. I opened my eyes just in time to see my opponent fall to the ground, the shaft of an arrow protruding from his skull, defeated. I could't belive it! Not only had I got my first two kills, but I had also won the Culling match. Victory was mine.

10/10 Can't wait for my next match, claymore, and a small loan of a million funk.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to recommend this game, I really do. It's some of the most fun i've had in a game in a while, and incredibly addicting with fairly well balanced gameplay. So why am I giving this a negative review? The updates.... The updates...

This game was great when it first released, and the first few big" patches were fairly good
date: balancing weapons/perks and lots of bug fixes. But soon after
recommended: the devs decided they needed to change the combat to make it more slow to make the more casual players happy... And then the game went down a steep hill and never recovered. The combat just got worse and worse until it's at this point
hoursPlayed: where it's so unplayable that the games playerbase has gone from a constant 4000 players every day

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lots of fun. Still has a lot of balance issues and some annoying bugs, but totally worth $15, even in its current state. Not to difficult to get into and snag a few wins. You don't even have to be super good. (It helps, but playing like a dirty backstabber can easily win you games.)

I have a real nerve problem with high-intensity one-chance games like this. My first match, my hands were shacking, palms sweating, I was fatfingering keys trying to craft what I needed before someone found me. I ended up winning. Killed 3 people.

In this game, being clever is just as important as being mechanically skilled. Don't think you can handle a fair fight? Throw down traps, plant some C4, maybe a claymore and bait your enemy into them. Let your enemies fight, and just when one is about to die, run in for some scummy backstabs on the one who is winning, then kill them both.

10/10 experience

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IT'S HUNGER GAMES! WHAT MORE DO YOU NEED????

One of the most amazing early access games I've played so far. Has a nice pvp system which is a bit hard to master and a bit challenging. Currently has only 1 map but it's fine. Lots of weapons, skins, airdrops, and perks to choose from. Has 2 modes, 1st is all vs all, the 2nd is teams of 2 people each (you can invite a friend on steam to team up with or just get a random one paired with you). Doesn't lagg much (if you get laggs there are easy ways to fix it). Cool and easy to learn crafting system with ingame currency.

After playing it barely 1 week, I give it 9/10, considering no game is perfect, and that it is still in early stages and has alot more to be added to it.

p.s:
THE RUSH OF ADRENALINE THIS GAME GIVES YOU IS SOMETHING ELSE!
So if you like it when your heart starts to pound hard when playing a game you should definately buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel like this game rules.
In its current state, a patch comes out every week that makes the game unplayable" for lots of players. A day or so later there is a hotfix that typically fixes almost all the new problems. The whole point of this early access state is to test out a buggy game that doesn't really work yet. This game is buggy
date: but it works a lot of the time and it's really really fun.\nI often find myself wondering why I love CSGO and Rocket League. They're really fun games too
recommended: but the urge to rank up and progress provides a strong drive to keep playing. The Culling has no rank system (yet). Every time I log into a match I'm playing for the sake of the game. Playing to win. There is no master class rank to work towards
hoursPlayed: but I'm always trying to get better and figure out the best perks. I love the game purely for the gameplay.\nOften the reviews will yell and shout about the combat being broken. The combat changes a little with every patch and sometimes changes a lot. But the truth is that these people aren't good at the game. They don't understand how to play
voteText: and they would if they played the tutorial. The Culling is highly competitive
helpfulPercent: despite not having ranked play. And this causes people to feel frustrated. You have to hone your skill in online play which is difficult because every match has very good players in it
votesHelpful: and to win you really do need to be the most cunning player.\nThis game was put on early access two months ago
votesTotal: and the rate at which updates and content get added has been absolutely astonishing. I recommend this game to anyone with a powerful computer who loves heartpounding PvP. To anyone else
votesFunny: it may be a risky buy in its current state.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yeah. I want my money back.

This game went from good, to bad, to worse. I bought this in early early access and have played a decent bit of it.

They've ruined this game, so bad. They won't listen to their fans, who've payed for an unfinished product to support development. The developers have taken our money, most likely bought themselves some new desks and computers, and have sent this game down the proverbial sh***er. Excuse my language, but it's true.

This game and these developers do not deserve your time, your money, or your frustration. They are nothing but frauds, who claim to be about the community and those who dedicate themselves to their game. If you like a horrible, destroyed game with flawed mechanics and bugs that will never be fixed, and constantly decaying content that loses sustenence with every patch, then this is the game for you. If you enjoy decent content, nice and friendly developers, or the idea that a company might listen to their paying customers. I encourage you to NOT buy this game UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE.

Don't make the mistake I made by paying for this game. Save your money for a developer that deserves it.




Don't get me wrong, the game actually was a very good concept in the beginning, and early builds were incredibly fun. If they'd just listen to their community instead of turning a blind eye to their paying customers, this game would definitely be going places far beyind triple-a titles. However the developers have ruined any chance of this game being worth your time or money.

tl;dr - Developers are frauds, don't give them your money. Don't give them your time. Spit on these developers and laugh as they burn for disrespecting their paying customers and ignoring any sensible feedback for their so called 'Game'


PS. I'd like a refund, which they won't give us because they know they'll never make the money back. They owe it to us, for what a mess theyve made of this. This doesn't even qualify as a game anymore, and it is not what I paid for in the slightest.
voteText: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the closest to hunger games I think anyone has come. It's not like Arma 3 or H1Z1 Battle Royals were you grab a gun then run around blasting people. The weapons and danger are weighty, combat is scary and risky no matter how good you are, weapons are scarce and you'll be lucky to see a gun once every few games. The thrill is amazing, you can really play any way you want. Nothing is quite as satisfying as stalking your prey through the woods for a few minutes and finally throwing a spear through their back. What a rush! Can't wait to see where they take this game.

Things I'd want to see done:
- Still needs optimizing, obveously, max graphics drop my fps faster than a stone cold stunner.
- Some minor balancing on weapons: a nerf on the taser and buff on some of the melee.
- I know they are making some new maps and I'd love to see something more lush. Stalking people through the woods is fun but there isnt a ton of cover.
- Bigger team options (3 players or 5 players)
- Finally, a voice proximity chat. Every survival battle game needs some trash talk!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was hesitant at first to get this game but I'm glad I did. This isn't your standard Battle Royale game which I like, we really needed a change from just guns. So the combat, I personally think it's really good and it requires a decent amount of skill to be successful. You actually have to think about when you're going to swing your weapon, when to block and push. If you just keep swinging your weapon you'll most definitely die. It's not perfect though it could use some improvments.

The optimization could also use some work as well but overall it's fine for me. 80% of the time my fps is over 60 but it can drop around 40 for me sometimes. It can get a bit boring playing by yourself after a while but I would highly reccommend playing this with a friend. It's a lot more enjoyable that way. There is a lot to talk about but I would just reccommend looking at other reviews or just watch YouTube videos of the game to find out more about it. Cba typing any longer so go do that xD

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the price, this is a solid title.

If I had to compare this title to another game, I'd say it's like H1Z1. Matches are 20 minutes long, though most games run about 12. You can die within the first 2 minutes if you're new, but don't be discouraged. Remember to use your block key, and use your shove against other players who are turtling (blocking alot).

The map isn't too big where you cannot learn it, and if you're afraid of campers, the game has many built in mechanics to combat that. Those being many poison gas stations, usually placed near buildings a player might hold up in, and at 10 minutes in the map, the game emits gas to push survivors to the map's center arena,

The game uses an ingame currency, where killing players and picking up items and surviving gives you points. These reset between matches, and can be used to call in air drops or open crates, which can give either buff items, or stronger weapons/armor.

Winning a match is difficult, but feels rewarding when pulled off. With an item drop system to keep you playing, the game has alot of replay value. Rewarding experience for hardcore gamers, easy enough where a casual player can hop in and not feel too lost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey, a quick change to my review!
I'm Australian, btw.
Now that AUS servers are coming, I'll most likely like the game better then.

Anyway, my review here;

The Culling is, very basically, a deathmatch/hunger games game. You find weapons, kill people, play with friends, play with bots, stuff like that.
It's got everything; simplistic crafting and inventory, fighting, teams, a rapidly closed-in arena, stuff like that.

For the moment, though I enjoy the game, it'll lag a whole lot for Aussies. So, if you're not an Australian, go ahead and get the game! Lots of fun to be had. And if you're Australian, then wait a little for the new servers, or just deal with it.

The only problem with lag right now is if you're trying to block or hit at the exact right time, it'll pause before actually hitting. So, way harder melee combat, though ranged is fine.

Either way, have fun slaughtering!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was hesitant at first to get this game but I'm glad I did. This isn't your standard Battle Royale game which I like, we really needed a change from just guns. So the combat, I personally think it's really good and it requires a decent amount of skill to be successful. You actually have to think about when you're going to swing your weapon, when to block and push. If you just keep swinging your weapon you'll most definitely die. It's not perfect though it could use some improvments.

The optimization could also use some work as well but overall it's fine for me. 80% of the time my fps is over 60 but it can drop around 40 for me sometimes. It can get a bit boring playing by yourself after a while but I would highly reccommend playing this with a friend. It's a lot more enjoyable that way. There is a lot to talk about but I would just reccommend looking at other reviews or just watch YouTube videos of the game to find out more about it. Cba typing any longer so go do that xD

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you enjoyed any other battle royale game ever, you'll realize how terrible those games are in comparison to The Culling. Ever tried to kill someone in H1Z1 only to have them prone, stand, and repeat to dodge" your bullets? Ever felt like the game is predetermined based on who manages to pick up the gun first? The Culling uses a smaller population per game on a still sizeable map
date:
and manages to condense the games into a beautiful 25 minute game. The crafting system allows you to take trash and make weapons that will actually allow you to contend with top tier weapons. The currency system makes for amazing interactions and allows for easier balancing of items based on the ability or inability to access items without feeling like it's unfair.

1. Craft a weapon 2. Loot a building 3. Recycle some garbage you probably won't use 4. Become a PCP addict and murder other PCP addicts with baseball bats and blowdarts. 5. Recruit your real life friends to do in game drugs with you in a game that's as addictive as actual PCP.

Buy the game right now. You need it."

Don't expect any quality pvp from this game. The hits delay, hitboxes are buggy at best and lag is insane. Want to play with a buddy? Better hope you don't get ganged up on before you meet him. 4/10 not a good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the battle royal games like H1Z1 or ark survival of the fittest,
i would realy recommend looking at this game.

combat style leans a bit more towards team fortress 2 instead of arma 3.
(i'm not saying its a team fortress 2 rip off)

no pay to win, the only payd things the game could add are cosmetics,
but it won't realy affect your gameplay if they'd do that.
because you get a cosmetc item each time you win or die in a round.
i noticed winning a round gave me better stuff, luck maybe?

F.U.N.C is a ingame currency, and will be lost on the end of a round, each round you'll start with a basic amount of like 16 F.U.N.C . This currency can be used to call in air drops, open lootcrates, craft weapons, traps, etc.

A round of culling will take up to 25 minutes.
When there are only 10 minutes remaining, the map will release toxic gasses near the edges, therefor forcing you to go to the middle, and meet up with everyone else to have a battle in the central stadium.
The map gets fully covered in gass when the timer hits 00:00, so no slacking or you'll die of the poison fumes!

one last thing for if you're not convinced into playing yet:
the game has a great taste of humor if you like sexual jokes while killing people :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love everything about this game, except that I cannot play it. If you live on East Coast, and like intense adrenaline fueling instincual action, then you will not regret buying this wonderful game. If you are anywhere other than EST then you likely will have way over 100 ping and lose every single fight to any player with 40. It's the way it is right now, and the unfairness boils my blood.

I'll rate it positive, because I believe the server issues will be fixed, and because I've already had hundreds of hours of massive fun, but if you live in Hawaii like I do, wait until there is a west coast server, unless you like 180 ping.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of reviewers are giving negative feedback due to the recent patches. And yes, the game hasn't been as good due to some of the changes. But still, there are few games that make you feel as tense as this one does. Fewer still that give you a true sense of achievement from winning a match. The developers are constantly trying new (drastic at times) things to rebalance the game, update on a regular basis, and will even admit a change was bad and throw it out sometimes.

For 15 dollars, it's a steal. I've made back about that much anyway just casually selling cosmetic items in the steam store.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love everything about this game, except that I cannot play it. If you live on East Coast, and like intense adrenaline fueling instincual action, then you will not regret buying this wonderful game. If you are anywhere other than EST then you likely will have way over 100 ping and lose every single fight to any player with 40. It's the way it is right now, and the unfairness boils my blood.

I'll rate it positive, because I believe the server issues will be fixed, and because I've already had hundreds of hours of massive fun, but if you live in Hawaii like I do, wait until there is a west coast server, unless you like 180 ping.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hunger games / Battle Royal with some mechanics that serioulsy favour people with more expereince. You will get farmed if you havent gone into the game with prior information and even then there are so many mechanics that put the player with more time ahead of you. The thing is The culling does it in a subtle - not immediatly apparant way. On the outside thngs look even - but there are many tricks and tactics to learn as well as things to unlock. Which brings me to my main point.

Once you have unlocked an air drop - you can call it in agian in subsequent games. Some of them contain exploives and firearms - which obvioulsy puts you ahead of the guy with the level 1 hammer. See my point?

Also there is too much of an advantage of waiting until 2 people have fineshed fighting and then ganking the survivor when they are low on health. The map needs to be bigger to mitigate this as much as possible (at least until the end)

Once this and a few bugs ironed out then the game will be playable as a short time waster. On thier road map they do say they are going to put in more mpas and other stuff - so if you want something more long term I would wait as see what they do with it.

RecommeNDed on the assumption the Devs do what they are saying they will.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm enjoying this game a lot so far although I don't have very much time played. Very fun and very addictive. Here's a short pros cons

Pros:
- Crafting system is easy to understand
- Perks allow player to choose a play style they enjoy
- Intense gameplay as the the time passes (The Culmination)

Cons:
- The block and push dynamics seem somewhat broken
- Weapons feel useless by not doing enough damage (long range bow headshots, sword slashes)
- Lack of in game team speak

Overall an enjoyable game. Especially with friends. Please keep it up devs!!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn a Battle Royale/Hunger Games-style arena showdown, In a 25-minute match narrated by a hilarious announcer, The Culling pits 16 players against each other, either in a free for all or duo-team matchup (with larger team matchups in the works.) The gameplay is based on a rock-paper-scissors style of combat, and is well balanced and fast-paced. My adrenaline gets pumping in nearly every game I take part in. The developers are incredibly responsive to feedback and work very hard on making The Culling a great game. It is definitely worth the price tag, and deserves a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I always wanted a game based off the Hunger Games, and this is the closest thing you'll get if that's what you're looking for. You'll have to craft supplies, traps, and weapons to defend yourself. There is also a crafting system which is very easy to understand in a short amount of time. There are also two game modes. One is a free-for-all, the other is with teams. Basically, in free-for-all you do whatever it takes to survive, whether it's by eliminating players (teams can be made in free-for-all, but treachery is inevitable), waiting the whole game out, or improving supplies.

When you're playing in teams mode, you'll be teamed up with another player, so your team will always be 2 players strong. It is crucial that you stick together and craft supplies and weapons for each other to ensure survival. Also, you must rely on each other in combat. Things can get messy pretty fast when you and three, four, or even five other players find themselves in the same area.

With all that being said, be warned of the following when you buy this game:

-Extremely unreliable (and unintelligent) companions in teams mode. There is a reason why most people play with their friends on here, because being teamed up with random people usually results in the person logging out or dying early because they're too freaking dumb to type in the chat box and communicate with you.

-A seriously strange combat system. Here's what you have in combat: Strikes, blocks, and shoves. Striking is so simple, guys. Just hit and cause damage. Blocking is a simple concept too. Just wait for the guy to strike and throw up a block to knock him off balance. But why do those things when you can just shove and strike the living ♥♥♥♥ out of your opponent? (technically, you'll just be shoving them most of the time) Shoves counter blocks, knock the player off balance, and keep them from doing anything to you in retaliation. So just shove them like an idiot and swing dat fist, rock, sword, or whatever you're using as a weapon and they'll be done in no time.

-A constantly changing environment. As time progresses, the map you're in gets more dangerous if you haven't already died. Poison gas will eventully be released and will expand all the way into the center of the map after a certain amount of time. That means when you first notice a green cloud of toxic-looking ♥♥♥♥, and you see somebody panicking and running away from it, you probably should be doing the same. The last piece of refuge until the gas completely covers the whole map is the very center. By the time it gets to that point, the most skilled players will most likely be fighting there. So if you're not one of them, then you might as well call it curtains.

-There are guns on this game. Be warned that if a person melees you while you have a gun, you'll end up being disarmed and the gun will be stuck on the ground.

-I am also terrible at this game, which is why I don't play it that much, so if you end up having me as a teammate, make sure you can do better than me, because we'll most likely end up dead. On the bright side, however, we most likely won't end up dying at the beginning. So we won't be the first ones to lose.

The game is being constantly polished, and has high potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Culling has a feel that is totally unique in itself. This game is obviously not a realism based shooter like Arma or a tiring rinse and repeat try hard competitive game like CSGO. Even though this is officially the third game to feature Battle Royal gameplay (following Arma 3 BR and H1Z1), The Culling feels completely unique from anything else. From the assortment of perks, weapons and craftable weaponry, every game is a different experience that is difficult to prepare for as there are no perfect counter for the ever rotating loadout of your enemies. You adapt, you survive!

In case you’re a newbie to Battle Royale, here is the JFYI. BR is a last man standing game type. You get one life. If you lose it..  you die and aren’t invited back. Over the course of twenty minutes or so the perimeter of the map slowly focuses in on a central point. At its absolute smallest everyone is practically kissing each other with blades and spears. The last person or team of two too survive, wins! This makes every game much more rewarding than your typical death match as everyone is always playing as if they’re the last player, in the last round, with their last life of a competitive tie-breaker final. For some, they may not have enough blood presume medicine for the stress nor skill required. For others, it’s life!

Style wise the game reminds me a lot of Gotham City Imposters. Gotham City Imposters was a SEVERLY under rated title that was KILLED by the failure known as Games for Windows Live (GFWL). Gotham City Imposters was a VERY unique FPS that went outside the comfort zone of traditional shooters with an art style equally complex as the diversity of combat.
The most appealing part of The Culling is the complexity of your evolving loadout and juggling between your perks for the best counters that will finish off your next opponent. The adrenaline rush that comes from knowing that you are living your one and only life keeps your ears perked like a blood hound on the scent of a blood bathed serial killer.

You have access to all of the perks/buffs from day one and the base loadouts are perfectly capable of winning you the game as everything is obtainable as pickups in game. Cosmetic drops are awarded at the end of your game regardless if it’s your untimely death or winning by the seat of your pants. Typically 10-25mins bouts. Cosmetic drops are one per game and are entirely up to chance. For air drops you start out with a handful in your inventory and you’re able to choose from one pre-game to call in during a match. These are purchased with in-game currency called FUNC.  Once you call a drop and open it the crate will forever be added to your inventory as a pre-game option. If someone else opens it before you, they get that drop added to their inventory! There are dozens of possible drops but in order to collect them all you need to select the random airdrop perk. This perk is pretty much so self-explanatory. You have no control over what drop you will receive but once you call it and open it, the ability gets added to your inventory to call during future matches. Eventually when you acquire enough drops you’ll have a nice collection to choose from. Ideally picking one that best complements your loadout.

For being an early access title there aren’t many issues. Any of the issues I come across seem to be addressed in upcoming patch notes. Gunplay unlike H1Z1 seems solid. The Culling is BIG on melee and picking up an actual handgun, SMG or rifle is a rarity. You are more likely to acquire an airdrop that comes equip with a gun than you are to find one out in the open. In 20hrs of playing I found one SMG in a loot pile and was able to kill another player for theirs. I do have gun crate drops but I’m still trying to acquire more crates with the random drop crate before I hone down on a specific crate to add to my loadout.

The Culling by no means beats Chivalry with how advanced the melee system is but it works, is fun and requires an acceptable amount of skill in order to master. The combat options are plentiful. The game feels rewarding and sometimes you are surprised with a victory while battling an opponent early on in the game to find that you’re the last survivor standing. When you do lose, it’s never a total upset. You’re always looking to jump back in for more and to use what you have learned to better yourself for your next match.

A++ would bang

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game used to be a very fun and competitive multiplayer game.
After some updates at the beginning of the game, I noticed a trend. The trend is that the updates are not thought out well, they continue to unbalance the combat, remove perks that helped the gameplay, nerf and buff some items causing the gameplay to suffer, and poor anti-cheating and hacking methods.
I got the game back before any updates came out and that build was the best build I have played on.
The devs did a really good job back when the game first released in Early Access, but now it seems like they don't care about the people playing the game with updates that are not really tested.
The devs made the Culling Test to try out these features, but it hasn't helped them. The devs need to hire people for a QA department to better address these issues before it gets even worse then it already has.
This game has potential but is being held back by updates that are running the game and don't seem to have the best intentions when they are released.
I would hold out on buying this product as the state it is in should not be worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never thought I'd be the kind of person to enjoy a game that is nothing but a competitive experience but I really do love it. The Culling has a little bit of everything, crafting, looting, melee combat, ranged combat and specialized Airdrops that one who can rack up kills can call in for the in-game currency FUNC.
While it isn't a perfect game it is a game that actually receives a lot of attention by the developers and is far from being a cheap cash grab like most early access games that never get finished. Yes, the latest updates have been rough, but guess what? It is very, very difficult to balance a PvP mulitplayer game that has melee weapon types, bows and arrows, guns and tools (stun gun, pepper spray, etc.). These developers actually listen to what the community wants, even put an entire system in the game that punishes people that team up to keep the game fair for everyone.

Please stop putting negative reviews on this game JUST because you didn't like the latest patches, you are effectively killing this game by giving this game a bad rating, keeping people from buying it in the future.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Culling is fantastic. It's what I've been waiting for.
Craft, hide, and fight your way to victory in the 20 minute, suspense filled games.
The end of the games are extremely intense. My heart was pounding in those final 2 minutes of the 1v1, where we went all out with bows, muscleman milk, iron 4 skin, guns, knifes and javelins. The feeling when you win is a huge rush.

However, I would like some things to be added such as stats and ranks, since there isn't really a massive incentive to keep on playing aside from the outfits you unlock, and more airdrops. Also, please nerf the SMG, it's basically a guaranteed win when you manage to get it.

Also, I have encountered a few bugs, but this of course is the day one patch. Currently, there are only severs in NA, so I wouldn't recommend buying it right now if you live in Asia or Oceania. I haven't experienced much lag at all here in the UK though. So I wouldn't hesitate to purchase if you have a decent internet connection over here.

EDIT: EU servers have been added!

9/10 - Will rise to a 10/10 if stats and ranks are added, along with more servers.

I havn't played a lot lately, infact I havn't played from the first patch that completely overhauled the combat.

After that first patch that made the combat an absolute discrace I have tried to play after patches, I've tried to learn the new system and look at it from an new perspective to see if I can play and have fun in the game again. Sadly I can't say that I enjoy this game anymore.

The game was a lot of fun in the beginning, the combat felt fluid and good in quite a high pace, and even if I died I always felt like it was my fault and me doing something wrong. Now however, whenever I play this game I feel cheated every game, the fighting feels slow and like you are held back by ropes or something, the reg of anything you do feels slow and often you just sitt there wondering what the hell just happened.
It just dosn't feel rewarding to actually take time and learn the system well, I can't see any point in the game. The fun for me was the combat, that rewareded playing well and was fast paced.
Also in the beginning the bow felt really good, I used to shoot bow my self a while ago and in the game it felt supricingly realistic, it felt a lot like it felt when I did it my self, but now I feels really strange, I can't explain it that well but it just feels like everything in the game works against you and tries to force the games pace down by just putting it in slowmotion and saying this is now normal speed".

I will keep my eye on this game troughout the future and see if they ever go back to the old combat that just game you that happy feeling when you did something well and made you feel beaten by the other player when you died instad of making you feel like you were cheated by the game it self.

All I can say is that I can't recommend this game as of now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the idea of savagely hunting down 15 victims, listening to an announcer who is just as snarky as Claptrap, and scavenging for supplies, then this game is for you!

This game is in alpha, so be patient with it. Clunky at times, but exciting nontheless. The thrill you get as you learn the layout of the island, and the feeling of your heart race as you hear footsteps nearby. Couple all of that with the shaking adrenaline rush after you successfully track down someone, bash/slash/shoot/explode/poison/snare/trap them to death, and then claim their loot..... There's no feeling quite like it. Look up at the sky when you're in game ;)

This game is unique and you owe it not only to yourself, but your country as well, to play this game. Which really works out if you're in the US because that's the only place the game works right now.

Things I'd love to see in the future: 1. A mini map? Even if it has fog of war sort of stuff, it's damn hard learning that giant ♥♥♥ level.
2. More levels, or more variety in what to find IN the levels. More caves/hard to reach tunnels that sort of thing.
3. Weather! This goes hand in hand with the more levels part. You could drop people in an abandoned research outpost way up in the arctic circle, where the cold is literally nipping at your health. Hell I'd take rain or sleet or tornados or ♥♥♥♥ing anything really.
4. The level should change more often than it does and sooner. At 17 minutes (example) start pushing everyone towards each other, instead of the last 9 or 10.
5. I hope the cameras come into play more often because it feels...useless to have them around otherwise. Maybe show a replay up on the scoreboard after a kill? SOMETHING!

For being in Alpha I'd give this game a 8 out of 10. Keep it up

Overall impressions: for an early access game this is a great buy, especially for the mere $15CAD you have to pay in order to purchase it. It's an incredible value. I'm looking forward to spring break!

I wholehearteadly recommend this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, definitely the best Hunger Games / battle royale type of game I've ever played. Would definitely recommend picking it up as it only costs around £10. 10/10 Worth the money.

Pros:
+ Amazing graphics
+ No micro-transactions (yet at least)
+ Very enjoyable combat
+ Great character customization
+ Nice free items after finishing a match
+ Free items after EVERY match
+ Easy controls
+ Queue waiting time is around 20 - 40 seconds
+ Have to actually craft weapons rather than just finding them like in H1Z1
+ Great servers
+ Weapons are balanced
+ Variety of weapons
+ Games don't take about 1 hour to finish
+ Not hard to find people around the map
+ No one wants to camp as it is completely boring in this game

Cons:
- Requires a decent PC to run it on medium to high graphics
- Changing mouse sensitivity is weird as it is a scroll bar instead of a number
- Can't change the crosshair
- NO VOICECHAT :(

Overall a great game as I've already mentioned and I would definitely recommend you pick it up as it is cheap. If you have played games such as h1z1, you will definitely like this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS.
THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS.

The culling
is an FFA or Teamdeathmatch where u have to survive and be the last man standing by any means, whether it means crafting a bow or knife, or simply looting abandoned buildings. Or you can go around collecting F.U.N.C which u then use to open crates, or summon special crates.

Now we all know that right now there is a ♥♥♥♥ ton of games, that in someway allow you to play this game mode (Last man standing, Hunger Games type ♥♥♥♥) - But the culling is focusing purely on this game mode, which is nice, and to some lengths it does a good job, combining the fact that you can craft your own weapons, and that there is the perks to assist your playstyle which i quite like and makes it a bit more interesting.

Let's get real

Plus side:
The graphics are decent
The sound is allso decent, but maybe a bit more one liners from the speaker, so it doesen't repeat itselft all the time, but this is just nitpicking.
The combat is cool, but again it's hard to judge with my fps.
The animations are cool.
The game is not very expensive which definetly helps it's cause.

Negative side:

Better optimisation (My pc is not from the stoneage)
♥♥♥♥♥♥ fps and a bunch of lags, and my computer is definetly half decent and shouldn't have any problems with this. <- This ways heavily in my judgement, cause for me, it is nearly unplayable.
Got randomly thrown out of a fight, with no message at all, that was a bit weird too, but only experienced it once.
Heard somewhere there are only american servers, maybe some servers in europe would help the lags.



Things i think are missing:

No ingame talk
Larger team vs team (more players on each team).
Maybe winning weapon skins
The bow feels kinda useless at the moment, maybe tweak that.


But all in all, it's a fun game, and it's not pretending to be anything other than it is, a fun time where you can release your anger upon players from the entire world, and u don't even have to worry about dropping the soap in prison !
But still at the current moment the major lags and low fps are just not worth it, even though it's cheap, like a 10 dollar crack ♥♥♥♥♥ kinda cheap.
If it ran better, then ♥♥♥♥ yea !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is great, but a bit annoying to get the hang of if you don't have experience with the combat system The Culling brings forth. And it gets more annoying if you are an AMD user, i basically found the config alteration on the subreddit and enabled that just to play this game at 55-100 fps. HOWEVER, the game does NOT require a high framerate to get played well. A higher framerate makes aiming easier. However thing is that melee is really good in this game if you know what to do. Which takes practice, but also makes it so that you can still do well even at 30 fps.

Biggest gripe i got with this game lands on things that surrounds the early access norm. The mechanics need tuning, certain weapons are rather powerful, and bugs still gotta get cleaned up. The tazer is a great example. Or 1 perk combined with a tier 3-4 weapon thrown into someone's back. The damage become over 50, where you only got 100hp max. Armor, perks, syringes and such can aid you of course if you want to survive that. But all this can make certain builds win more than not, thus meaning that the game need tuning there. It is however really fun, and many early fights can run on for quite some time if you are aware and ready to play smart making even short games fun.

Ratings and technical details below. Do forgive my messy writings, i am not a pro reviewer.

The graphics look great, max as well as min. Game can use a ton of optimization but it works. The mechanics are well made and make sense for this type of game despite some glitches. While it takes time to get used to all this it is worth it for the savagery this game offers. Even if you get 100 ping.

So for play-ability, my rating lands on 7/10. It could be a lot worse, and we have seen worse examples in the past. Servers only exist in the US and Europe. Thus connection lag become annoying in fights, but if you live close it is manageable.

Graphics lands on 8.5/10. It does not need to be advanced nor over the top to work, which is clearly demonstrated if you bother to track down how to set shadows OFF and everything else put on the lowest. If you need the extra frames that is (Nvidia users got an advantage here i do believe).

Overall Rating is at 9/10 on Early access. Thanks for reading this far, i will dive deeper into the main content for those that care about this below. I decided to put it last not to spoil, for people that care about this & want to jump in fresh.

The game's style is based on the battle royale" game mode we have seen in H1Z1
recommended: in other games and even as a mod in CS:GO. It works well in a gun heavy game as with H1Z1 but falls a bit flat because the map and randomization of the loot in H1Z1 can randomly annihilate you because of it's inconsistent nature and map size. While you can play around this with skill

votesTotal: poison darts
votesFunny: blunt weaponry
commentsCount: bow and arrow and more. In H1Z1 though
column16: even if you get to a good location it might be dominated by someone that got the only rifle at said area. This is assuming you even got a spawn that is close to where there is decent or a lot of loot. The consistency of getting weapons in The Culling is thus a lot better since you spawn close to crates and buildings by default. Unlike in H1Z1
column17: at times. And it takes 15seconds to just get to 1 good location normally once you spawn in The Culling. Combine that with how it is impossible to get "1-tapped" and you got yourself a game that brings a ton to the table in an interesting way. Combine this ALSO with good perks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Preface
⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮⁮The Culling is a pvp-centric, arena-based combat game containing light King Of The Hill elements. Initially, your objective is to simply survive as well as to optimally gather defensive/offensive loot until the secondary objective, which is to slay any human you can find, comes into play and then the blood-bath ensues

While published through Early Access Release, The Culling offers a robust array of features including over 40 perks to customize your playstyle, multiple weapon types containing three tiers in each, an array of traps, and custom airdrops earned through F.U.N.C. to help the players end-game experience. To go more in depth on these features, you're now going to read through a list of highlighted details within The Culling that I'd like to expand on that might help you make the choice to buy the game.

‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎   ‎‎Highlighted Features
• Perks
Mentioned above, the Perks in this game are already pretty extensive. As of now you can choose a combination of three perks in your loadout to aid you in your conquest to become the killer of men. Perks range from silencing player movement/crafting to doing 40% more backstab damage when attacking with any blade. You can truly customize your gameplay experience and even switch it up every now and then if you get stale. I currently run the silent axe wielding maniac who regenerates stamina twice as fast.

• Optimization
This was another feature that initially impressed me in how refined it was considering the Early Access release. At first I was running great, and then decided to max every graphic setting and am still playing beautifully. Also, compared to titles like Rust, The Culling doesn't put half as much of a tax on your hardware while running.

• Dynamic Map interaction
This is something that consistently proves to be even better than I previously assumed to me. Not only are there map-to-map ranomizations of hazard tanks that can be strategically activated to explode-outward a noxious wall of gas in the near-by perimeter. Alondside this, you can craft Punji Sticks that cause incompacitating vomitting along with a visual debuff that causes distortions on-screen. Also, alluding to my first sentence, I've very recently found out that doing things like placing punji sticks jammed into health stations cause them to short-circuit and go out of use. Very good for the strategic minded individual.

• Traps
I wanted this section to be its own highlighted topic following the previous one that slightly mentioned one trap mostly because traps in this game can be utailzed to quite literally change the entire tide of the game. You can punji stick/snare a large area so that any human who comes into your combat-domain is automatically at a disadvantage. You can place found targeted explosives, posion blowgun people while snared, etc. It's just all around a smart thing to utalize when playing The Culling.

• F.U.N.C.
F.U.N.C is an in-game currency earned through most of the actions executable in The Culling. Killing players, being the first player in a structure, walking 100 meters, recycling found loot.. these are just some of the methods for gathering F.U.N.C. You can then expend this gathered F.U.N.C on everything from health at any red station to crafting traps and armor.


Suggestions
• Third person
I really think a game like this benefits from a 3rd person option, and would love seeing something like this implemented in The Culling some time in the future.

• Gun rebalancing
You can currently get guns by either being supremely lucky & opening a blue crate, or by expending only the largest amounts of funk to attain these devices of instant rage. They've currently made these weapons balanced" by implementing a feature where if any player hits you while you hold a gun (you cant block with a gun) then it basically has an 80% (hell maybe even higher) chance to just fly out of your hand onto the ground as if you dropped it. So
hoursPlayed: but at short range they aren't. Instead of this I propose simply removing all airdrops that have guns in them
voteText: and making them something that you can only attain via three crate monte or Viva Pinata. There's no reason for everybody to have the ability to get guns if the way you balance them makes them only balanced from a certain range.\n\nIf we did this
helpfulPercent: everyone would be forced to the middle who wanted a gun. This would make for more fast paced gameplay as well as more of a reason for people to go to the aforementioned events
votesHelpful:
as I often find myself the first person getting all the gear.

Conclusion
Honestly
votesTotal: so far I've really enjoyed my time playing The Culling. I think that as it stands the price is wonderful for the content
votesFunny: and very reflective of a level-headed dev team honestly which is super respectable. I would definitely recommend this game to any friends
commentsCount: and despite my preface containing discontent for biased comparisons I do think that this stands the test of playability with titles such as H1Z1: King of the Hill/Rust battle royale. Providing that the devs stay on their toes and provide us with some nice updates I think that this could become a favorite title for me very easily."
